caption.p: Summary of medically important and most commonly occurring viral hemorrhagic fevers

tr.td: Reported geographic distribution

Most wide spread tick-borne viral infection in humans. Reported from more than 50 countries in Africa, South East Europe, Middle East and Asia. Including China, Turkey, Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece, Iran, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Egypt, Nigeria and South Africa
Angola, Democratic Republic of Congo, Kenya, Uganda, Zimbabwe
Sierra Leone, Guinea, Liberia and Nigeria
Endemic in more than 50 countries in tropical regions of Africa (44 countries) and South and Central America (12 countries)
Cumulative occurrence/prevalence
Sero-prevalence of up to 20% in endemic areas in people with history of tick bites

Only 466 cases reported from 1967 to 2014 (including cases associated with exportation of infected monkeys to Europe, Russia and USA). Outbreaks often involve single cases. Two bigger outbreaks reported in DRC and Angola in 1998–2000 and 2004–2005, respectively
Up to 500,000 cases in West Africa per annum
Up to 130,000 cases with hemorrhagic manifestation per year by estimation
Sero-prevalence of up to 55% in certain communities in endemic areas
Mode of transmission
Mostly through tick bites, or other contact with infected ticks, or infected tissues and blood. Nosocomial transmission has been reported, but human-to-human transmission limited
Spill over from cave dwelling bats, exact mode of transmission unclear
Human contact with infected rodent urine and fecal material. The latter may be aerosolized and transmitted via this route
From day feeding Aedes mosquitoes, particularly A. aegypti
Human-to-human transmission through direct and close contact with infected persons
Reservoir host and vector
Domestic livestock and small mammals
Believed to be cave dwelling bats such as Roussettus aegyptiacus
Mastomys natalensis (or the multimammate mouse)
Maintained in sylvatic cycle in nature involving certain primates and canopy dwelling mosquitoes. May establish in urban setting involving Aedes aegypti
Ticks, particularly Hyalomma ticks
Case fatality rate
Up to 30% in hospitalized cases
Up to 90% in outbreaks
Up to 20% in hospitalized cases, but up to 80% of people infected do not develop signs and symptoms of Lassa fever
Up to 50% in hospitalized cases
